head.title: A 9-Year-Old Suspect in Court: 'Traumatized,' Her Lawyer Says

hedline.hl1: A 9-Year-Old Suspect in Court: 'Traumatized,' Her Lawyer Says

block.p: A 9-year-old girl accused of stabbing her 11-year-old friend to death in a tussle over a ball was taken from her round-the-clock suicide watch, dressed in a black dress with matching shoes and driven to Brooklyn Family Court yesterday, where her lawyer entered pleas of not guilty to charges of manslaughter.

The killing happened on Monday in her family's seventh-floor apartment in the Linden Houses in East New York, Brooklyn. The police said the 9-year-old stabbed Queen Washington, 11, once in the chest with a steak knife.

A 9-year-old girl accused of stabbing her 11-year-old friend to death in a tussle over a ball was taken from her round-the-clock suicide watch, dressed in a black dress with matching shoes and driven to Brooklyn Family Court yesterday, where her lawyer entered pleas of not guilty to charges of manslaughter.

The killing happened on Monday in her family's seventh-floor apartment in the Linden Houses in East New York, Brooklyn. The police said the 9-year-old stabbed Queen Washington, 11, once in the chest with a steak knife.

The girl has been charged with manslaughter, assault and weapons charges in a juvenile delinquency petition filed by the city's Law Department. She is being held at a nonsecure facility in Queens, said her lawyer, Nicole Barnum. She was returned there yesterday, with the next hearing in the case set for June 17.

''She's very young, very immature, and has a very limited capacity to understand what happened and the magnitude of what happened and the process she's now in, and I think she's very traumatized by being separated from her mother because she's such a young girl,'' Ms. Barnum said after the hearing. ''She's very confused. I think it's important to remember she's a 9-year-old girl who is now separated from all emotional support from the people she has in her life and all the people who love her.''
During the hearing, the prosecutor, Suzette Rivera, an assistant corporation counsel, asked that the child undergo a psychological evaluation. Ms. Barnum said she already had.
''She is not a threat to herself at this time,'' Ms. Barnum said, adding that the girl is under a 24-hour watch. ''She's not alone at any time.''

The girl's mother stood silently with two relatives during the hearing. On Monday, the mother had gone upstairs in her building to borrow a comb for the girl when the fight with Queen took place. Neighbors said she had been gone only a few minutes.
At the end of the hearing, Judge Jane Pearl leaned forward, spoke the girl's name, and told her, ''Take care of yourself.''

The viewing for Queen will take place from 6 to 9 p.m. today at Holy Tabernacle Church of Deliverance in Bushwick. The funeral will be at 9 a.m. tomorrow at the church, with burial to follow at Rosehill Cemetery in Linden, N.J.
